title: Nanoscale Insights into the Thermal Phase Behavior of All-Inorganic Halide Perovskites by In Situ 4D STEM
content: The investigation of phase transitions within halide perovskites is crucial for the progression of advanced photovoltaic and optoelectronic devices, where thermal stability and structural integrity are critical under operational conditions [1, 2]. This study concentrates on the cesium lead-based halides (CsPbX3, where X = Br or Cl), which are known in the halide perovskite family due to their promising optoelectronic properties [4]. We aim to elucidate the intricate phase transitions these compounds undergo upon thermal variation. Utilizing in-situ four-dimensional scanning transmission electron microscopy (4D STEM) capabilities and eaSI™ technology, as integrated within DigitalMicrograph® version 3.6, we have conducted a comprehensive investigation of the thermal-induced phase behavior of these perovskites. This approach captures their structural evolution across a temperature range from sub-ambient to the melting point. Energy-filtered 4D STEM data were acquired using a JEOL ARM300F microscope outfitted with a GIF Continuum® and post-GIF K3® detector from Gatan. Temperature modulation of the samples was achieved using a DENSsolutions heating holder for heating and a Gatan LN2 holder for cooling.
